questions.text: The ilio-psoas muscle is inserted on which of the following part of the femur?
questions.solution:
Lesser trochanter (Option B):

  • It is a conical eminence directed medially and backwards from the junction of the posteroinferior part of the neck with the shaft.
  • The psoas (Greek loin) major is inserted on the apex and medial part of the rough anterior surface
  • The iliacus is inserted on the anterior surface of the base of the trochanter and on the area below it.
  • The intertrochanteric line provides (Option D):
    • Origin to the highest fibres of the vastus lateralis from the upper end.
    • Origin to the highest fibres of the vastus medialis from the lower end.
  • The following are attached to the greater trochanter (Option A):
    • The piriformis.
    • The gluteus minimus and medius
    • The obturator internus and the two gemelli ( tricipetal tendon)
    • The obturator externus
  • The quadrate tubercle of intertrochanteric crest (Option C) receives the insertion of the quadratus femoris

Tag: Bone of lower limb

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 18, 19

questions.text: Which of the following bursa is inflammed in case of Clergyman's knee?
questions.solution:
Subcutaneous infrapatellar bursa (Option C):

  • Subcutaneous infrapatellar bursa lies in front of lower part of the tibial tuberosity and of the lower part of the ligamentum patellae.
  • Subcutaneous infrapatellar bursitis is called 'clergyman's knee'.
  • It occurs due to the friction of bursa against the tibial tuberosity due to kneeling (e.g., kneeling during prayer by Christian priests/clergymen, roofers, and floor tilers.

Subcutaneous prepatellar bursa (Option B):

  • Prepatellar bursa lies in front of the lower part of the patella and of the upper part of the ligamentum patellae.
  • Prepatellar bursitis is called 'housemaids knee' or miner's knee.

Suprapatellar bursa (Option A):

  • It lies between tendon of quadriceps and anterior surface of femur.

Deep bursa (Option D):

  • Two deep bursae are also present. These are suprapatellar bursa and deep infrapatellar bursa.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: pneumonic - CH-IP

  1. Clergyman's knee - Infra patellar bursitis
  2. House maid's knee - Pre-patellar bursitis

Tag: Knee joint

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-2, 4th Edition, Page Number - 430, 431

questions.text: A 35 year old man during walking bends or waddles on the right side to clear the left foot off the ground. Which of the following nerve is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
• When the glutei medius and minimus (of right side) are paralysed, the patient cannot walk normally.
  • He bends or waddles on the right side (in given case) or paralysed side to clear the opposite foot, i.e. left, off the ground. This is known as lurching gait.
  • When bilateral, it is called waddling gait.
  • So in above case injury is on right side.
  • Gluteus medius and minimus is supplied by superior gluteal nerve.
  • So in above case right superior gluteal nerve is affected.
  • Trendelenburg's sign:
    • Acting from below, both the gluteus medius and minimus prevent the unsupported side of the pelvis from sagging during walking and thus maintain the horizontal level of the pelvis provided the hip joint and neck-shaft angle of the femur are normal.
    • When the gluteus medius and minimus of one side are paralyzed due to injury of the superior gluteal nerve.
    • The pelvis sags on the healthy side if that foot is off the ground.
    • As a result, the person walks with a lurching gait. This is clinically known as Trendelenburg's sign

Option B - Left superior gluteal nerve injury - pt waddles on left side to clear the right foot of the ground

Option C and D - Inferior gluteal nerve supplies gluteus maximus, its main action is extension at hip joint and lateral rotation of hip

In the above image, right gluteus medius is paralysed, so when the patient tries to lift left leg off the ground, the pelvis sags towards left side(injured right gluteus medius can't abduct the pelvis) to compensate this patient waddles towards the right side

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Right superior gluteal nerve palsy - pelvis sags to left side, patient waddles to right side

Left superior gluteal nerve palsy - pelvis sags to right side, patient waddles to left side

B\L superior gluteal nerve palsy - waddling gait

Tag: Gluteal region

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 80, 81; Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-2, 4th Edition, Page Number - 351

questions.text: Which of the following artery is palpated against the calcaneus 2 cm below and behind the medial malleolus?
questions.solution:
• The posterior tibial artery (Option D) pulsation can be felt against the calcaneus about 2 cm below and behind the medial malleolus.
  • It's difficult to palpate plantar arteries (Option B), as they are in the sole of foot.
  • The anterior tibial artery (Option C) runs vertically downwards to a point midway between the two malleoli where it changes its name to become the dorsalis pedis artery.
  • Pulsations of the dorsalis pedis artery (Option A) are easily felt between the tendons of the extensor hallucis longus and the first tendon of the extensor digitorum longus

Tag: Back of leg

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 130, 132

questions.text: Given figure shows the dermatomes of the front of the lower limb. Which of the following dermatomes supplies to area marked with blue colour?
questions.solution:
Figure below is showing dermatomes of lower limb

  • The cutaneous innervation of the lower limb is derived:
    • Mainly from segments L1 to L5 and S1 to S3 of the spinal cord; and
    • Partly from segments T12 and S4.
  • As a rule, the limb is supplied only by anterior primary rami. The exception to this rule is that the skin of the superomedial quadrant of the gluteal region is supplied by the posterior primary rami of nerves L1 to L3 and S1 to S3.
  • The dermatomes of the lower limb are distributed in an orderly numerical sequence.
  • Along the preaxial border from above downwards, the dermatomes are T12, L1 to L4.
  • The middle three toes, the adjoining area of the dorsum of the foot and the lateral side of the leg are supplied by segment L5.
  • Along the postaxial border from below upwards, there are dermatomes S1, S2, S3.

IMPORTANT DERAMTOMES

Tag: Dermatomes of lower limb

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 154, 155

questions.text: Area marked in the figure with * is supplied by which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous innervation of sole of foot:

  • The skin is supplied by following cutaneous nerves (as shown in the figure below)
  • Medial calcanean branches of the tibial nerve (Option C):
    • To the postero-medial portions of heel.
  • The medial plantar nerve (Option D):
    • To the larger, anteromedial portion including the medial 3 1/2 digits.
  • The lateral plantar nerve:
    • To the smaller anterolateral portion including the lateral 1 1/2 digits.
  • The Saphenous nerve (Option A):
    • To the Small area on medial side.
  • The sural nerve (Option B):
    • To the small area on lateral side.
  • These nerves are derived from spinal nerves L4, L5 and S1.

Tag: Cutaneous innervation of lower limb (sole of foot)

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 135; Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-2, 4th Edition, Page Number - 407, 408

questions.text: Which of the following inheritance pattern is seen in case of hemophilia?
questions.solution:
Inheritance:

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance (Option C):
    • Marfan's syndrome
    • Achondroplasia
    • Brachydactyly
    • Neurofibromatosis
    • Huntigton's disease
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance (Option D):
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Inborn errors of metabolism
    • Hemoglobinopathies, e.g., sickle cell anemia and thalassemia.
    • Hemophilia C
  • X-linked dominant inheritance (Option A):
    • Vitamin-D resistant rickets
    • Hypophosphatemia
    • Xg blood group
  • X-linked recessive inheritance (Option B):
    • Hemophilia A and B
    • Colour blindness
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Duchenne muscular dystrophy
  • Y-linked inheritance
    • Hypertrichosis
    • Webbed toes
    • Porcupine man
  • Multifactorial inheritance:
    • Cleft lip
    • Cleft palate
    • Club foot
    • Congenital dislocation of hip
    • Congenital heart disease.

Note: Hemophilia A and B are X - linked recessive inheritance

Hemophilia C - Autosomal recessive inheritance

Tag: Medical genetic (inheritance)

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology, Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition page Number - 355 to 357

Pedigree Chart:

  • It is dependent on the study of segregation of marker genes in families with genetic disorders.

choices.text: Loss of sensation on anterolateral aspect of leg

questions.text: 35 years old male was brought to emergency department. On x-ray he was diagnosed with fracture of neck of fibula. After two months it was revealed that he was also having injury to common peroneal nerve. All of the following symptoms may be present in the patient, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Effects of injury to the common peroneal nerve:

  • The common peroneal nerve is extremely vulnerable to injury as it winds around the posterolateral aspect of the neck of the fibula.
  • At this site it may be injured by the direct trauma, fracture neck of fibula, or tightly applied plaster cast.
  • The characteristic clinical features are as follows
  • Motor loss:
    • Foot drop (Option C), due to the paralysis of muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg (dorsiflexors of the foot).
    • Loss of extension of toes (Option A), due to the paralysis of extensor digitorum longus and extensor hallucis longus.
    • Loss of eversion of foot, due to the paralysis of peroneus longus and peroneus brevis (evertors of the foot). So (Option B) is false about the patient.
  • Sensory loss:
    • on the anterolateral aspect of the leg (Option D), and whole of dorsum foot except the areas supplied by the saphenous and sural nerves.

Tag: Popliteal fossa

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-2, 4th Edition, Page Number - 457

choices.text: Lateral rotation of the femur on tibia
It is brought by quadriceps femoris

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the locking of knee joint?
questions.solution:
Locking of the knee:

  • When the foot is on the ground, the locking is defined as the medial rotation of femur on the tibia during the terminal phase of extension of the knee.

Unlocking of the knee:

  • When the foot is on the ground, the unlocking is defined as the lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia during initial phase of the flexion.
  • The unlocking is brought about by the popliteus muscle.

Difference between locking and unlocking of knee joint

Tag: Knee joint

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-2, 4th Edition, Page Number - 432

choices.text: Fibular collateral ligament, lateral meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament
Tibial collateral ligament, medial meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament
Fibular collateral ligament, lateral meniscus, posterior cruciate ligament
Tibial collateral ligament, medial meniscus, posterior cruciate ligament

questions.text: Which of the following is correct structure of unhappy triad of knee joint?
questions.solution:
Unhappy triad of the knee joint:

  • A combination of injury of the following structures is called "unhappy triad" of the knee joint.
    • Tibial collateral ligament
    • Medial meniscus
    • Anterior cruciate ligament
    • So (Option B) is correct.
  • Injuries to cruciate ligaments:
    • The anterior cruciate ligament is more commonly damaged than the posterior ligament.
    • The anterior cruciate ligament is injured in the anterior dislocation of the tibia; whereas, the posterior ligament is injured in the posterior dislocation of the tibia.
    • If the anterior cruciate ligament is torn the tibia is pulled excessively forward on the femur (anterior drawer sign)
    • If the posterior cruciate ligament is torn the tibia is pulled excessively backward (posterior drawer sign).
  • Injuries to menisci:
    • Strains in a slightly flexed knee, as in kicking a football, the meniscus may get separated from the capsule, or may be torn longitudinally (bucket-handle tear) or transversely.
    • The medial meniscus is more vulnerable to injury than the lateral because of its fixity to the tibial collateral ligament, and because of greater excursion during rotatory movements.
    • The lateral meniscus is protected by the popliteus which pulls it backwards so that it is not crushed between the articular surfaces.
  • Injuries to collateral ligaments:
    • They are less common and may be produced by severe abduction and adduction strains.
    • The tibial collateral ligament is more prone for injury compare to the fibular collateral ligament.

Tag: Knee joint

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-2, 4th Edition, Page Number - 433
